item.title: Report E-2025020238
item.description:
Report E-2025020238

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-19T06:18:35+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-14
  • City: WEST SACRAMENTO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 13, 2025, one (1) 1-liter bottle of nitric acid was damaged and released approximately one (1) liter of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services who dispatched a crew from Graymar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the site. GES crews deployed a neutralizing agent to the impacted area and worked it in with hand tools until a neutral pH reading was confirmed. The damaged bottle and box were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal. The PPE and neutralizing agent were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025020233
item.description:
Report E-2025020233

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-19T06:18:35+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-13
  • City: LONG BEACH
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 13, 2025, two (2) 50-pound bags of sodium hydroxide were torn in transit and released approximately two (2) ounces of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the site. GES personnel used hand tools to collect all spilled material from the impacted trailer. All collected material, two (2) damaged 50-pound bags of sodium hydroxide, and all PPE were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for future transport and disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025020216
item.description:
Report E-2025020216

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-17T21:14:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-21
  • City: SAN JOSE
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 17:51 PM ET, Ed Ramos with USJ contacted the call center to report a spill that occurred inside of a trailer in San Jose, CA. The spill consisted of approximately half a gallon of Alphaguard Puma Base Coat, which was released from a 1–5-gallon metal bucket due to other freight puncturing the bucket during transit as the shipper packed it too closely to another pallet, impacting the inside of the trailer. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the terminal, who stated they will clean the spill and place the waste into a 1–35-gallon metal drum.

  • Description: The package was found by the package handlers wet and leaking paint. QA was called to clean the area and take the package to the hazmat cage. Upon inspection of the package, the inside did not have any filament and did not have a limited quantity diamond sticker attached. The damage to the contents was the paint can was dented and that caused the lid to vent.

item.title: Report I-2024100111
item.description:
Report I-2024100111

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-15T00:55:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-10
  • City: RIALTO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ENVIRONMENTAL LOGISTICS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A 30 gallon metal drum of lighters was being shipped under special permit 13179. At the time of the incident the drum was on a pallet and had been removed from a 48' van trailer and was to be moved from one pallet to another to be placed back on the 48' van trailer for further transportation. There was no other handling to take place. As an employee grabbed the drum by hand to move it the lid blew off hitting the employee. There was no continued release of butane. The butane that had accumulated in the drum did flash and it is estimated that all the butane was used in the flash. No release, nor continued release of butane was observed. A single butane torch appears to have been defective and caused the incident. As the lighters were being repackaged a butane torch was ignited just by moving it. The lock was found to be defective. The torch was made inoperable by taping the valve closed.

item.title: Report I-2024070112
item.description:
Report I-2024070112

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-15T00:55:32+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-17
  • City: RIVERDALE
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EAST PENN LOGISTICS LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 1
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 313220
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: An East Penn Manufacturing Co. driver was heading west bound on Kamm Ave approaching Jameson Ave. The other driver was headed northbound on Jameson Ave. approaching Kamm Ave. The other driver disregarded the posted stop sign and came into the path of the East Penn driver. Collision occurred and the East Penn truck rolled on to its side and came to a final stop at the northwest corner of the intersection. This was a T-Bone event. Police came to the scene and requested help for the cleanup. East Penn hired a hazardous waste cleanup contractor to clean up the batteries that were on the ground and take them back to their shop. East Penn then went back to the contractor to pick up the batteries to take them back to East Penn's Salt Lake City, UT facility. The batteries were then sent to one of the East Penn's tolling smelters for proper disposal of the batteries at a secondary lead smelter for recycle. East Penn also hired a contractor to do the remediation cleanup of the soil and incident area. The clean up was completed and overseen by the Fresno County Enviromental Health.
